indicators.justification:
Paraguay's Healthcare Ministry's General Directorate for Strategic Information in Healthcare (i.e. DIGIES) publishes data related to civil registration and vital statistics (CRVS). However, the latest data available is from 2018. Its open data section is limited and only has one working dataset (1). In the "Estadísticas en Salud" drop-down menu, a list of URLs lead to pages where xls/xlsx files contain relevant data. In general, these files contain multiple sheets with summary data presented in tables that are not ready for data analysis. Historical data availability varies across files and sections; a few have data going back to 1997, but the latest updates available are 2017 or 2018.

Causes of death seem to be standardized following PAHO's international statistical classification (2)(3). However, identifiers are not independent variables and appear in a second sheet in each file.

Sources:
(1) Ministerio de Salud Pública y Bienestar Social (MSPBS). 2021. "Datos Abiertos". Dirección General de Información Estratégica en Salud (DIGIES). http://portal.mspbs.gov.py/digies/datos/
(2) PAHO. 2003. Clasificación Estadística Internacional de Enfermedades y Problemas Relacionados con la Salud: Décima Revisión. http://ais.paho.org/classifications/chapters/pdf/volume2.pdf
(3) Ministerio de Salud Pública y Bienestar Social (MSPBS). 2021. "Indicadores de mortalidad". Dirección General de Información Estratégica en Salud (DIGIES). http://portal.mspbs.gov.py/digies/02-indicadores-mortalidad/

indicators.justification:
Paraguay published open data on COVID-19 vaccinations (1) days after a member of Congress resigned after being caught illegally getting a COVID-19 vaccine before her time (2). Essentially, the evidence of corruption in the application of vaccines early on generated social pressure from citizens who demanded to know whether other people were jumping the line. The Healthcare Ministry began publishing data only 2 days after the Senator's resignation was submitted (3). The Healthcare Ministry also created a designated site for people to check anyone's vaccination status by simply providing their ID and birthday data (4).

Sources:
(1) Ministerio de Tecnologías de la Información y la Comunicación (MITIC). 2021. "Registro de Vacunaciones COVID-19". Portal de Datos Abiertos Gubernamentales. https://www.datos.gov.py/dataset/registro-de-vacunaciones-covid-19
(2) La Nación. 3 May 2021. "Renuncia 'indeclinable' de Mirta Gusinky tras vacunación irregular". https://www.lanacion.com.py/politica/2021/05/03/renuncia-indeclinable-de-mirta-gusinky-tras-vacunacion-irregular/
(3) Ministerio de Salud Pública y Bienestar Social (MSPBS). "Listado de vacunados". https://www.vacunate.gov.py/index-listado-vacunados.html
(4) Ministerio de Salud Pública y Bienestar Social (MSPBS). "Consulta de Agendamiento para la Vacunación contra el COVID-19". Portal Vacunate. https://www.vacunate.gov.py/formularios/consulta/index.html

indicators.justification:
Paraguay's National Land Registry (i.e. Servicio Nacional de Catastro - SNC) offers public access to search functionalities to locate land parcels and their owners (1). However, users can only manually check (i.e. search by zooming into a map) land parcels to get their unique identifiers, which can then be used in a different section to check who/what owns said land parcel (2). A 2018 publication by the Treasure Ministry shows the SNC has data on rural properties, National Parks, and Indigenous Lands (3). Moreover, Art. 30, Law 109/1991, states the National Land Registry must "keep an updated registry of all land properties, identifying their legal owners..." (4).


Sources:
(1) Servicio Nacional de Catastro (SNC). 2021. "Consulta de Mapa Catastral". https://www.catastro.gov.py/visor/?snc=geo

indicators.justification:
Budget and spending data can be found in Dataset 3 of the Finances Ministry's Open Data Portal (1). According to the latest available Open Budget Survey (2), only economic classifications are aligned with an internationally agreed standard, in this case the IMF Manual (3). There are functional, program, and administrative classifications; those sections were filled thanks to an interview with the Finance Ministry's Accounting and Open Data Director, María Teresa Agüero (4).

(3) IMF. Mar 2018. "Manual de estadísticas de finanzas públicas 2014". https://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/gfs/manual/pdf/2014companion/SpanishGFSM.pdf
(4) Interview with Maria Teresa Aguero, Accounting and Open Data Director. Finance Ministry.

indicators.justification:
Only Art. 19 in Decree 4064/2015 superficially covers the  topic of efficiency of public information sources (1). This article states that "the Unified Portal for Public Information must have tools that allow citizens to know the level of efficiency of public sources in their handling of access to information requests, response times, and level of citizen satisfaction". Hence, the lack of specific requirements in legislation and policies limits the publication of relevant data on the performance of the access to information law. In this way, the graphics presented in the Unified Portal for Public Information and the ability to download its source data represent the only available way to understand basic aspects of said performance (2).

indicators.justification:
Government support for data reuse steadily declined since 2017. From 2014 to 2016, annual hackathons and events promoted open government data reuse. This decline was notorious in the last known data reuse event led by the government in 2019, the "IAckathon" (i.e. Artificial Intelligence Hackathon), which focused on government closeness, government openness, government intelligence, government efficiency, and trustworthy digital government (1). Noticeably, the Terms and Conditions for this event did not mention open data or the suggestion to focus on that type of datasets from government (2).

indicators.justification:
The pandemic crisis brought open data to the forefront in very specific situations related to the transparency of the emergency loans the government got to face the crisis. This was a reaction to civil society and citizens demands for transparency in the use of the 1,6 billion dollars the government got in loans. As a result, Paraguay's first ever mention of open data in law took place in the COVID-19 National Emergency Law 6524/2020 (1). This was not initially achieved, but eventually the Portal "Rindiendo Cuentas" (Providing Accountability) published open data on the use of emergency funds (2). However, in general, there has been a regression in terms of open government data publication, provision, and update. The Healthcare Ministry Open Data Portal was shut down late in 2019. The ICT Ministry latest approved budget for 2020 has no specific line assigned to open data (3).

indicators.justification:
Civil servants in 15 public institutions received trainings about open data during the relevant time-frame for this study (1). In an interview, Open Government Director at the ICT Ministry, Derlis Meza, explained that most of the trainings were provided virtually due to the pandemic. Hence, there are no URLs or articles to these events. He clarified that they have 3 types of training: a. Introduction to open data, b. Prioritizing data that could be published, and c. Opening and publishing data. According to Meza, most trainings are about the first 2 topics, while the third happens rarely for public agencies willing to publish data. Hence, most trainings are open to technical and non-technical staff.

Sources

indicators.justification:
In Paraguay, only 2 out of 5 political integrity data are available online in some form, i.e. asset declarations and RTI performance information. In the case of asset declarations, this is only searchable by the national identification number (ID)(1), which only leads to PDF documents where the relevant data, assets and liabilities, must be manually extracted. Hence, interoperability across different political integrity datasets is minimal and when it is possible, it requires a high degree of data wrangling.

Interoperability with other relevant datasets such as public procurement, land, company information, and public finance is similarly limited in Paraguay. Land data is not open; company information has only two variables (name and VAT identifier or RUC), and public finance cannot be directly matched to procurement data (2). It is this last dataset, procurement, which has the most interoperable fields because government contractors and providers must register with their VAT identifier, their legal address, and their national ID. This means that, if the assets and liability data can be extracted and structured, it can be matched to public procurement.

Sources:
(1) Contraloría General de la República del Paraguay. 2020. "Portal de Publicaciones de Declaraciones Juradas de Bienes y Rentas". https://portaldjbr.contraloria.gov.py/portal-djbr/
(2) Dirección Nacional de Contrataciones Públicas. 2021. "Portal de Datos Abiertos". https://contrataciones.gov.py/datos/

indicators.justification:
Paraguay lacks legislation on the comprehensive protection of personal data or data privacy. The Constitution does not address protection of personal data directly. Existing legislation on personal data and current proposals invoke Art. 33 of the Constitution, which talks about the right to intimacy. The Constitution's Art. 45 "Of rights and guarantees not enunciated" establishes that the lack of legislation cannot deny rights and guarantees inherent to the human nature. Habeas data appears on Art. 135 (1).

However, in October 2020 a bill was enacted by Congress on the subject of personal credit data (2). TEDIC, an NGO that specializes in data privacy and Internet governance, emphasized that said bill focused on privacy of credit data, not on the protection of personal data (3). Late in April 2021, the Coalition of Personal Data in Paraguay (Coalición de Datos Personales en Paraguay) presented a bill to Congress on a comprehensive framework for the protection of personal data in Paraguay (4).

The National Emergency Law (6524/2020) enacted due to the COVID-19 pandemic stated in its Art. 49: "... to keep the security and protection of personal data that is collected, stored, processed and/or transmitted through technological systems or mediums implemented due to this emergency situation" (5).


Sources:
(1) Constitución Nacional de la República del Paraguay. 1992. https://www.bacn.gov.py/constitucion-nacional-de-la-republica-del-paraguay
(2) Ley de Protección de Datos Personales Crediticios, 6534. 2020. https://www.csj.gov.py/cache/lederes/G-211-28102020-L-6534.pdf

indicators.justification:
Decree 4064/2015 (1) which regulates Paraguay's Right to Information Law 5282/2014 (2) is the first legal document that mentions and defines "open data". 

Annex II of Decree 4064/2015 is titled: "License for Use of Public Information". This serves as a standard license for public information. However, it requires three things for it to be applicable.

It must be noted that Decree 4064/15 Articles 18 and 20 assign responsibility for guidelines and digitalization norms as well as technological development to the ICT Ministry (i.e. MITIC, previously known as SENATICs).

indicators.justification:
Law 5033/2013 and its modifications by Law 6335/2019 regulate the sworn statements of assets and liabilities required to all public employees (1)(2). No articles mention the publication of the data contained therein. However, in 2020, through a lawsuit based on the Access to Information Law (5282/2014), the Supreme Court ruled the publication of about 20 years worth of sworn statements of high ranking public employees (3). In short, while publication is not mandated by law, there is now precedent that these statements can be made public through formal access to information requests and litigation.

indicators.justification:
In 2017, a draft bill to regulate lobbying and personal interests was introduced to Congress (1). It's been in study phase ever since. This draft includes transparency measures that would require a registry of lobbyists that would be publicly accessible. A 2019 publication by the OECD shows Paraguay has no legislation in place to regulate lobbying (2). In 2020, the government of Paraguay presented its "National Transparency, Integrity, and Anticorruption Plan 2021-2025" (3). Objective 4.7 of said plan is titled "Regulation of Conflict of Interests and Lobbying Activities".

indicators.justification:
Paraguay has recently modified its Law on Political Financing (1)(2). However, while it was one of the assumed objectives, the modifications did little to increase transparency in political financing according to Marta Ferrara, executive director of Semillas and expert in political financing (3). Ferrara also mentions a key loophole, which is that political parties are not subject of Law 5282/2014 on the Access to Public Information. In fact, the Electoral Justice Tribunal (Tribunal Superior de Justicia Electoral), the agency in charge to monitor and publish information on political financing received by political movements, alliances, and parties has not published anything on its webpage, contrary to what the law mandates (4).

indicators.justification:
There is no law that requires public consultations on rulemaking (1). Hence, the "public audiences" (i.e. audiencias públicas) is the closest figure that has some regulation through Paraguay's National Senate Resolution 574/2014 (2). Still, public audiences are voluntary as is participation in them. The public's contribution is not binding. In fact, public consultations only seem to be required by law in aspects related to indigenous communities and the environment (3).

indicators.justification:
The only available evidence of impact by using data from the national land registry is in the area of environmental justice (1). However, this was more the achievement of the CSO that led the case, rather than the availability of the data for public use. IDEA, an environmental NGO, used a formal access to information request to get land registry data in 2018 (2), which allowed it to match land ownership with other external data in order to denounce illegal deforestation.

indicators.justification:
The pandemic brought the need to access open government data to a few broad discussions. Mainly, the huge loans the government received (over USD 1.6 billion) made citizens suspicious that corruption would plague the funds use. This is how for the first time, years of public employees assets and liabilities sworn statements were published (1). This is also what motivated many citizens to monitor public procurement cases involving the Healthcare Ministry due to the spike in medicine prices. Key civil servants from said ministry had to resign after irregularities were exposed in procurement processes (2). Two major government providers for the Healthcare Ministry were suspended for the same reason (3). These situations were also largely due to organised civil society and the tools they developed (4)(5). These tools allowed to show how, in a period of a few years, certain politicians increased their assets in over 1000% (6). In another case, one of the richest municipalities did not invest for an entire year in education infrastructure even though about USD 2 million were available (7). Two research projects also used open data to analyze procurement processes by the Healthcare Ministry in a comparative manner (8) and procurement processes by local government with emergency funds (9).


Sources:
(1) ABC Color. 24 Jun 2020. "Publicación de Declaraciones Juradas: Esto fue una victoria de la ciudadanía". https://www.abc.com.py/nacionales/2020/06/24/publicacion-de-declaraciones-juradas-esto-fue-una-victoria-de-la-ciudadania/
